member.name: T:Outpost31.Core.Avatar.AvtrSystemInfo
member.summary: Logic for Avatar system/system codes/environments/etc.

member.name: P:Outpost31.Core.Avatar.AvtrSystemInfo.AvtrSys
member.summary: The Avatar System that the Tingen Web Service will interface with.
member.remarks:
The Avatar System determines what Avatar environment the Tingen Web Service will interface with.
Netsmart defines the following Avatar Systems when deploying Avatar at an organization:
LIVE
UAT
SBOX
BUILD
member.value: The Tingen Web Service works with the LIVE or UAT Avatar Systems.

member.name: P:Outpost31.Core.Avatar.AvtrSystemInfo.AvtrSysCode
member.summary: The Avatar System Code used to login to Avatar.
member.remarks:
The Avatar System Code determines(in part) what Avatar functionality a user has access to while they are logged into an Avatar System.
Organizations may have many different Avatar System Codes, but only a few Avatar Systems. In addition, the Avatar System Code may be similar or the same as the Avatar System.

member.name: M:Outpost31.Core.Avatar.AvtrOptionObject.Finalize(Outpost31.Core.Session.WsvcSession,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Finalize an OptionObject so it can be returned to Avatar.
member.remarks:
An OptionObject must be finalized before being returned to Avatar.
The method:
Ensures that all required components of the OptionObject are valid
Assigns an error code to the object
Assigns an error message to the object
The error code must be one of the following:
0 No action taken
1 Returns an Error Message with an "Ok" button, and stops further processing of scripts.
2 Returns an Error Message with "OK" and "Cancel" buttons, and stops further scripts the user clicks "Cancel"
3 Returns an Error Message with "Ok" button
4 Returns an Error Message with "Yes" and "No" buttons and stops further scripts the user clicks "No"
5 Returns a URL to be opened in a new browser
6 Returns a form to be opened in Avatar
Examples of common error codes:
1
Typically used when you want to display some information to the user, and prevent them from taking an action.
For example, you want to let the user know that a field contains invalid data, they cannot proceed until they correct it.
3
Typically used when you would like to notify the user of something, but it is not critical to their current task.
For example, you want to wish the users a happy birthday!.
4
A combination of the above two, where you want to display a message to the user, but also allow them to take an action.
For example, you want to let the user know that there is a potential misspelling in their text, but they can choose to ignore it and proceed anyway.
member.param: The Tingen session instance.
The OptionObject error code.
The OptionObject error message.

member.name: M:Outpost31.Core.Avatar.AvtrOptionObject.CheckExistance(ScriptLinkStandard.Objects.OptionObject2015)
member.summary: Validates whether the provided OptionObject instance exists.
member.param: The OptionObject instance to validate.
member.returns: A string indicating the validation result.

member.name: T:Outpost31.Core.Logger.LogEvent
member.summary: Methods for logging various types of events.

remarks.note: The following types of logs are supported:

member.name: M:Outpost31.Core.Logger.LogEvent.Critical(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Critical logs indicate a significant failure with the Tingen Web Service.
member.param: The Avatar environment that the Tingen Web Service has interfaced with.
The log message to write.

member.name: M:Outpost31.Core.Logger.LogEvent.Debug(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Debug logs are used when developing the Tingen Web Service.

remarks.para:
Debug logs should be commented out in production code, or removed
if they are not needed.

member.param: The Avatar environment that the Tingen Web Service has interfaced with.
The name of the assembly generating the log entry.
The full path of the file being logged.
The name of the method being logged.
The line number being logged.
The log message, which defaults to "Debug log." if not specified.

member.name: M:Outpost31.Core.Logger.LogEvent.Debuggler(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Debuggler logs are temporary logs used when you want to debug something specific.

remarks.para:
Debug logs should removed before deploying to production.
Since debuggler logs may be written very quickly, there is a 1000ms delay
before committing to file.

member.param: The Avatar environment that the Tingen Web Service has interfaced with.
The log message, which defaults to "Debuggler log." if not specified.

member.name: M:Outpost31.Core.Logger.LogEvent.Primeval(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Primeval logs are used when the advanced logging infrastructure isn't available.

remarks.para:
Primeval logs should removed before deploying to production.
Since primeval logs may be written very quickly, there is a 1000ms delay
before committing data.

member.param: The Avatar environment that the Tingen Web Service has interfaced with.
The log message, which defaults to "Primeval log." if not specified.

member.name: M:Outpost31.Core.Logger.LogEvent.Trace(System.Int32,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Trace Logs are used for debugging and tracking the flow of the application.

remarks.para:
Trace logs work a little differently than other logs. They are assigned a "TraceLevel" between 0 and 9,
which is defined in Tingen_Data\WebService\%avtrEnv%\Config\Runtime\TngnWbsv.config:
0 - None
1 - Methods
2 - Conditional statements
9 - All

Each TraceLevel is cumulative, so if you set the level to "5", it will also include all logs
from TraceLevels 1-4. Care should be taken to not set the level too high in production, since
it can impact performance and generate a large amount of log files.
As long as the web service is functioning as expected, the TraceLevel should be set to "0"
Since the TraceLevel handles what Trace Logs are written, Trace Log statements should not be
commented out of production code.

member.param: The Trace Log level.
The Avatar environment that interfaces with the Tingen Web Service.
The name of the assembly generating the trace.
The full path of the file being logged.
The name of the method being logged.
The line number being logged.
The message to include in the trace log. Defaults to "No message." if not specified.

member.name: M:Outpost31.Core.Logger.LogWriter.WriteLogToFile(System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.String})
member.summary: Writes log content to a local file.
member.param: A dictionary containing the file path and log content. The key "FullPath" specifies the full path to the file, and the key "LogContent" specifies the content to be written.

member.name: M:Outpost31.Core.Utility.Du.DuFile.ReadLocal(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the contents or status of a file.
member.param: The path to the file.

remarks.para:
If the file exists and has content, that content is returned.
If the file does not exist, or exists but is empty, an error message is returned.

member.returns: The content or status of the file.

member.name: M:Outpost31.Core.Utility.Du.DuFile.ReadAndVerifyLocal(System.String,System.Collections.Generic.List{System.String})
member.summary: Returns the contents (if valid) or status of a file.
member.param: The path to the file.
A list of valid content.

remarks.para:
GetContent() returns the contents or status of the file.
If the file contains data, that data is checked against the list of valid content.

member.returns: The verified content or status of the file.
